title: 108_s321
content: The Act may be cited as the "Firefighting Research and Coordination Act" and includes provisions for new firefighting technology. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to include the development of new technology for evaluating firefighting technologies. The Administrator will work with various organizations to develop measurement techniques and testing methodologies. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is being amended to include the evaluation of new firefighting technologies such as personal protection equipment, advance warning devices, enhanced vision equipment, victim locating devices, incident command information tools, virtual reality training methods, and robotics. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is being amended to include the evaluation of new firefighting technologies such as robotics and remote-controlled devices. The act also supports the development of new voluntary consensus standards for firefighting technologies. New equipment purchased through the assistance program must meet or exceed applicable voluntary consensus standards. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to authorize appropriations for the development of new firefighting technology, with $2,200,000 allocated for fiscal year 2004. COORDINATION OF RESPONSE TO NATIONAL EMERGENCY. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to establish mutual aid systems for national emergencies, providing technical assistance and training for threat assessment, equipment deployment strategies, and resource information collection. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to establish mutual aid systems for national emergencies, providing technical assistance and training for threat assessment, equipment deployment strategies, and resource information collection. The Administrator of the United States Fire Administration will develop model mutual aid plans for intrastate and interstate assistance, and report on the strategic needs for deployment of volunteers and emergency response personnel. The Firefighters' Safety Study Act (15 U.S.C. 2223e) requires a national credentialing system for firefighters during national emergencies. The Director of FEMA must update the Federal Response Plan within 180 days to include plans for responding to terrorist attacks in urban areas, including fire detection and suppression. A report must be submitted to the Senate and House Committees on Science detailing the actions taken. SEC. 4. TRAINING. Section 8(d)(1) of the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to include strategies for building collapse rescue, use of technology in response to fires and national emergencies, tactics for dealing with terrorist-caused catastrophes, familiarity with FEMA's Federal Response Plan, and leadership skills. The National Fire Academy focuses on leadership, strategic skills, technology application, terrorism response integration, and fire tactics at US ports. The Superintendent may consult with other agencies on curriculum development, and the US Fire Administration coordinates with other programs to avoid duplication. The Administrator of the United States Fire Administration coordinates training to avoid duplication with other federal agencies and establish a mechanism for eliminating redundant programs.
